Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Utilization of Smart Materials and Predictive Modeling to Integrate Intracellular Dynamics with Cell Biomechanics and Collective Tissue Behavior

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this research project is to employ programmable materials from the field of biomaterials science, particle-tracking algorithms from the fields of biomechanics and biophysics, and molecular probes from the fields of cell and molecular biology to track and model the interaction of multiple intracellular components and the resultant large-scale cellular behaviors. A grand challenge in biomechanics and mechanobiology is that of understanding the complex interactions that occur between intracellular structures and how those interactions produce function at the cell and tissue levels. Through three objectives, this project will yield a method for quantitatively characterizing interactions between intracellular components and linking those patterns with large-scale behaviors such as cell polarization. First, the biomechanical sequence of cell polarization at the intracellular level will be elucidated via automated, synchronized tracking of multiple components in single cells in highly constrained environments. Second, cell polarization will be induced in individual cells using smart substrates and patterns in intracellular components will be linked to this large-scale cell behavior. Third, cell polarization will be studied and modeled, from the intracellular to multicellular levels, in a model of contact inhibition release/localized epithelial-mesenchymal transition with high cell densities. Coordinated cell movements are critical to biological processes such as embryonic development, cancer progression, and wound healing. Although cell movement is generated by structures inside cells, it is not known how interactions of those structures produce cell movement and resulting organization within groups of cells. This project will answer that question. A new computational approach will quantify the simultaneously interactions of several different important structures inside cells. New smart material will be used to trigger changes to cell movement, and the computational approach will determine how interactions of structures inside cells also change. Both low cell densities, where cells interact rarely, and high cell densities, where cells are always touching as happens in living organisms, will be studied. A model for collective movement of large groups of cells that can make predictions about tissues formation and disease will be developed.

Society will benefit from the technical and professional development of the individuals involved, important advances in the fields of biomechanics, biophysics, and biology, and breakthroughs that can be anticipated in healthcare fields. Research, education, and diversity at both collaborating institutions will be further integrated through a yearly summer research program that will recruit exceptional Hampton University students as undergraduate researchers.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Coordinated cell movements are critical to biological processes such as embryonic development, cancer progression, and wound healing. Although cell movement is generated by structures inside cells, it is not known how interactions of those structures produce cell movement and resulting organization within groups of cells. This project created new understanding to help answer that question.

A new computational approach was used to quantify the simultaneously interactions of several different important structures inside cells (Image 1). New “smart” materials were used to trigger changes to cell movement, and the computational approach was used to determine how interactions of structures inside cells also changed (Image 2). Theoretical and computational models for collective movement of large groups of cells that can make predictions about tissues development and disease were developed (Image 3). Collectively, these outcomes provided new tools to enable innovative biomechanics and mechanobiology research in diverse fields, new theoretical models for better understanding of biomechanics and mechanobiology in diverse systems, and new fundamental understanding of biomechanics and mechanobiology at multiple length scales and in multiple systems. These outcomes provide both knowledge that can broadly improve understanding of processes such as wound-healing, embryogenesis, and cancer tumorigenesis, and knowledge that can specifically improve understanding of processes such asthma.These research outcomes were shared with the scientific community through 10 archival, peer reviewed, indexed journal publications, 4 publications in preparation or submitted, 1 indexed conference publications, 4 oral presentations, 5 poster presentations, 47 invited talks, and 16 other presentations.

Research, education, and diversity at both collaborating institutions was further integrated through a yearly summer research program that recruited exceptional Hampton University students as undergraduate researchers (Images 4 and 5). The workshop supported project advancement and student training, including research expertise, collaborative ideas, professional skills, and exposure to different institutions for all participants, thereby advancing discovery and promoting teaching, training, and learning. Hosted by each of the three laboratories involved in the project, students gained hands-on experience of how to synthesize and prepare shape-memory polymers (the “smart” materials used in the project) with Dr. Henderson, how to label and image cells with Dr. Turner, and how to model active matter with Dr. Manning.

In addition, society is anticipated to further benefit in the long-term from the technical and professional development of the individuals involved, important advances in the fields of biomechanics, biophysics, and biology, and breakthroughs that can be anticipated in healthcare fields.


 

 


Last Modified: 06/08/2017
Modified by: James H Henderson

Images (1 of )
  • Labeled nuclei (cyan) and Golgi bodies (magenta). A fully automated method tracks nuclei centers and Golgi body centers (circles). Arrows illustrate the vector connecting nuclei and Golgi body centers in cases where the algorithm determines the two are close and moving in a coordinated manner.
    Giuseppe Passucci
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    James H Henderson
    Interaction of structures inside cells.
  • AFM of a gold-coated, shape-memory polymer substrate of the kind frequently in the project to trigger changes in cell motility. When triggered, the wrinkles seen here form underneath cells cultured on an initially flat surface, prompting an increase in polarized cell motility. Scale bar is 20 ?m.
    Richard Baker
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    James H Henderson
    ?Smart? material used to trigger changes in cell movement.
  • Predictions from a model for cell motility in dense monolayers. Left: a phase diagram describing cell motility. Right: the cell shapes and the cell trajectories in the two phases. This prediction (with no fit parameters) has been validated in cultured cells from lungs of human patients with asthma.
    M. Lisa Manning
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    James H Henderson
    Modeling collective movement.
  • Smart Material Advances and Advanced Research Training (SMAART) workshop 2015 participants Donmanique Hardy (left) and Joyrie Dickerson (right) examine with Dr. James Henderson shape memory polymer samples they prepared during the workshop.
    Syracuse University
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    James H Henderson
    SMAART workshop participants in the lab.
  • Smart Material Advances and Advanced Research Training (SMAART) workshop 2015 participants Joyrie Dickerson (center left) and Donmanique Hardy (center right) discuss with Dr. Lisa Manning (right) and PhD student Giuseppe Passucci (left) an active matter model they prepared during the workshop.
    Syracuse University
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    James H Henderson
    SMAART workshop participants discuss active matter modeling.
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Coordinated cell movements are critical to biological processes such as embryonic development, cancer progression, and wound healing. Although cell movement is generated by structures inside cells, it is not known how interactions of those structures produce cell movement and resulting organization within groups of cells. This project created new understanding to help answer that question. A new computational approach was used to quantify the simultaneously interactions of several different important structures inside cells (Image 1). New "smart" materials were used to trigger changes to cell movement, and the computational approach was used to determine how interactions of structures inside cells also changed (Image 2). Theoretical and computational models for collective movement of large groups of cells that can make predictions about tissues development and disease were developed (Image 3). Collectively, these outcomes provided new tools to enable innovative biomechanics and mechanobiology research in diverse fields, new theoretical models for better understanding of biomechanics and mechanobiology in diverse systems, and new fundamental understanding of biomechanics and mechanobiology at multiple length scales and in multiple systems. These outcomes provide both knowledge that can broadly improve understanding of processes such as wound-healing, embryogenesis, and cancer tumorigenesis, and knowledge that can specifically improve understanding of processes such asthma.These research outcomes were shared with the scientific community through 10 archival, peer reviewed, indexed journal publications, 4 publications in preparation or submitted, 1 indexed conference publications, 4 oral presentations, 5 poster presentations, 47 invited talks, and 16 other presentations. Research, education, and diversity at both collaborating institutions was further integrated through a yearly summer research program that recruited exceptional Hampton University students as undergraduate researchers (Images 4 and 5). The workshop supported project advancement and student training, including research expertise, collaborative ideas, professional skills, and exposure to different institutions for all participants, thereby advancing discovery and promoting teaching, training, and learning. Hosted by each of the three laboratories involved in the project, students gained hands-on experience of how to synthesize and prepare shape-memory polymers (the "smart" materials used in the project) with Dr. Henderson, how to label and image cells with Dr. Turner, and how to model active matter with Dr. Manning. In addition, society is anticipated to further benefit in the long-term from the technical and professional development of the individuals involved, important advances in the fields of biomechanics, biophysics, and biology, and breakthroughs that can be anticipated in healthcare fields.
